snippet: In Harris v. Quinn, the decision was not the deathblow to unions, but it showed an antipathy toward collective bargaining and workers’ rights.
abstract: Editorial criticizes Supreme Court decision excusing certain workers from having to contribute fees to the unions that represent them; argues ruling signals court's antipathy to collective bargaining and workers' rights; holds ruling has hurt the interest of home-care aides and threatens security of eight million workers who are represented by public-sector unions nationwide.
lead_paragraph: In Harris v. Quinn, the decision was not the deathblow to unions, but it showed an antipathy toward collective bargaining and workers’ rights.

headline.main: Limiting Rights: A Hit to Collective Bargaining
